awd_titl_txt: Workshop:  Cross-Disciplinary Investigations in Imaging and Image Analyses
awd_abstract_narration: This proposal requests funding for a two-day workshop on cross-disciplinary investigations in imaging and image analysis.  This workshop will bring together representatives from US and foreign academic institutions representing a variety of disciplines engaged in imaging and imaging analyses.  The workshop envisions large-group keynote presentations by prominent researchers and break-out sessions on specific topical areas.  One goal of the meeting is to facilitate education, training and informational exchange among multiple scientific disciplines including humanities, arts, social science, science, and computational researchers to address related research challenges for which image and imaging analysis is both a means and end (visualization, virtual spaces, et al.)   The organizations planning the event include the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), the University of Illinois School of Art and Design, and the Institute for Computing in Humanities, Arts, and Social Science (I-CHASS) as well as individual stakeholders in the broader community.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
1           Abstract

Designed to facilitate information exchange education and training among several scientific disciplines, the workshop “Cross-Disciplinary Investigations in Imaging and Image Analyses” brought together representatives from academic institutions in the United States and abroad, as well as from American museums and other archives. Humanists, social scientists, artists, and archivists were paired with computer scientists and information technology specialists at the workshop in order to present complementary views on topics related to imaging and image analyses of historical artifacts.

The workshop was organized as collaboration between the National Center for Supercomputing Applications (NCSA), the Institute for Computing in Humanities, Arts, and Social Science (I-CHASS), the University of Illinois’ School of Art and Design, and the Center for Digital Humanities (CDH) at the University of South Carolina. It took place at the NCSA facility in Urbana, Illinois on April 1-2, 2011. The main workshop organizers were: Peter Bajcsy, NCSA, Univ. of Illinois; Jenifer Guiliano, CDH, Univ. of South Carolina; Kevin Hamilton, School of Art and Design, UIUC; and Simon Appleford, ICHASS, Univ. of Illinois.

2           Workshop Execution

Cross-Disciplinary Investigations in Imaging and Image Analyses brought together multi-disciplinary stakeholders in the burgeoning field of imaging and image analysis to offer a unique opportunity for cross-collaboration and information-exchange through the use of computational techniques to bridge humanities, arts, and social science research. During a two-day workshop, it covered topics including: 2D scanning technologies, 2D and 3D imaging and analysis, content-based image and video retrieval, and preservation strategies. The workshop created opportunities for the humanities, arts, social science and archival communities to explore scientific instruments applied to imaging historical artifacts, as well as opportunities for the scientific community to investigate the adaptation of existing web 2.0 technologies to distributed research. The major activities of the project were focused on designing the workshop theme, announcing the workshop and soliciting contributions, managing workshop contributions and registration, performing local arrangements for the workshop, moderating the workshop sessions and round table sessions, providing audio-visual support and recording the workshop, preparing workshop surveys and processing obtained feedback, and summarizing the workshop findings in the final report.

3           Summary of Workshop Outcomes

Our research findings are in the information obtained from the workshop participants about domain specific technical challenges in dealing with digital artifacts, and about the challenges of multi-disciplinary collaborations. Key to our discussions during the workshop was a revelation of the different emphases and approaches to similar processing problems, across the domains of commercial, non-profit, and educational research. Distinctions between work with 2-D, 3-D or time-based artifacts seemed less important than did distinctions between which stage of processing most interested each researcher. For some, the content of the research lies in acquisition of data, such as the problem of discerning 3-D models of historical buildings from old maps and image scans of texts. Others focus more on the processing of already acquired data, such as in automated paragraph detection, historical map scale estimation or authorship attribution to artistic hand from manuscript illustrations. For still others, most of the research could be found in devising new ways of retrieving and browsing the data, as in the matching of ancient maps onto contemporary topographical datasets in Google Earth.

The intellectual merit of Cross-Disciplinary Investigations in Imaging and Imaging Analyses lies in information exchange, cross-disciplinary collaboration, and cross fertilization of on-going and future efforts in the area of imaging and image analyses. Our intention was to expose approaches to imaging and image analyses from the diverse communities of humanities, arts, social science, and computational researchers. The contributions within the discipline of computer science were accelerated by a more robust understanding of digital humanities and its associated computer science problems. These problems, as listed by our participants during their presentations and discussions, include: algorithm development to automate image information retrieval, scalability of algorithms with the existing digital volumes, management of large volumes of digital data and collaborative technologies to explore share data and conduct joint scientific investigations. The dialog between computer scientists and humanists, artists, social scientists, librarians, museum curators, and archivists enabled everyone to explore how new discoveries could be achieved in a collaborative way and how efficiency of data intensive studies could improve. The workshop also emphasized strategies for collaboration and devoted significant attention to relationship development between these communities. For the general public, these outcomes potentially influence the access to a wealth of information about historical artifacts, events and knowledge using the contemporary digital information technologies. The workshop has identified several technical, legal and social challenges that could be tackled for the benefit of the general public.
